docs.abstract: At first I was nervous about trying to run a marathon while eating a vegan diet, but the more I trained, the better I felt, writes Christine Frietchen.
docs.snippet: At first I was nervous about trying to run a marathon while eating a vegan diet, but the more I trained, the better I felt, writes Christine Frietchen.

docs.lead_paragraph: Australopithecus sediba apparently lived on a diet of leaves, fruits, wood and bark, scientists report, while other hominins in Africa mainly consumed grasses.

headline.seo: Australopithecus Sediba Preferred Forest Foods, Fossil Teeth Suggest
headline.main: Some Prehumans Feasted on Bark Instead of Grasses
headline.print_headline: Some Prehumans Feasted on Bark Instead of Grasses

docs.abstract: Scientists are surprised to find that Australopithecus sediba apparently lived on a diet of leaves, fruits, wood and bark, while other hominins in Africa mainly consumed grasses; skeletons show that they adapted for tree climbing as well as upright walking; their behavior is more like that of modern chimpanzees, which tend to ignore savanna grasses, or the more apelike hominin Ardipithecus ramidus, which lived largely on hard foods some 4.4 million years ago.
docs.snippet: Australopithecus sediba apparently lived on a diet of leaves, fruits, wood and bark, scientists report, while other hominins in Africa mainly consumed grasses.

docs.lead_paragraph: A groundbreaking geriatrician, Dr. Linda P. Fried seeks to “reframe our understanding of the benefits and costs of aging.”

headline.kicker: Profiles in Science | Linda P. Fried

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Linda P Fried, groundbreaking geriatrician and dean of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University; Fried focuses her attention on the costs and benefits of aging, which she sees as a key issue in solving the public health problems of the 21st century.
docs.snippet: A groundbreaking geriatrician, Dr. Linda P. Fried seeks to “reframe our understanding of the benefits and costs of aging.”

docs.lead_paragraph: THE FACTS Soy milk, tofu and other soy products contain phytoestrogens, chemicals that can mimic the behavior of the hormone estrogen. Because estrogen fuels many breast cancers, soy has long been a source of concern: Can it heighten the risk of breast cancer or raise the odds of recurrence?

headline.main: Really? The Claim: Eating soy increases the risk of breast cancer.

docs.abstract: Studies have found that eating soy does not increase the risk of breast cancer. (M)2

docs.lead_paragraph: With the publication this month of ''Eat and Run: My Unlikely Journey to Ultramarathon Greatness,'' by the vegan distance runner Scott Jurek, vegan diets have become a wildly popular topic on running-related Web sites. But is going totally meatless and, as in Mr. Jurek's case, dairy-free advisable for other serious athletes, or for the rest of us who just want to be healthy and fit? To find out, I talked with three experts about why, and whether, those of us who are active should consider giving up meat or more. None of the experts are themselves vegan, though two are vegetarian: David C. Nieman, a professor of health and exercise science at Appalachian State University, who's run 58 marathons or ultramarathons and has studied runners at extreme events; and D. Enette Larson-Meyer, an associate professor of human nutrition at the University of Wyoming, as well as a longtime competitive athlete and author of ''Vegetarian Sports Nutrition.'' A third expert, Nancy Clark, who describes herself as ''two-thirds vegetarian'' -- she doesn't have meat at breakfast or lunch, but does at dinner -- is a sports nutrition expert in Massachusetts and the author of ''Nancy Clark's Food Guide for Marathoners.''

headline.main: Phys Ed: Can Athletes Benefit From a Vegan Diet?

docs.abstract: Interview with exercise experts David C Nieman, Nancy Clark and D Enette Larson-Meyer, centering on whether athletes can benefit from a vegan diet. Photo (M)
